Introduction This is an example of using R to run many regressions and collect a single regression coefficient from each model. The code uses R’s list-columns feature.
Data library(forcats) library(tidyquant) date_start <- "1960-01-01" dat <- tq_get(c("UNRATE", "CPIAUCSL", "CPILFESL"), get = "economic.data", from = date_start) ur <- dat %>% filter(symbol == "UNRATE") %>% rename(ur = price) %>% select(-symbol) dat <- filter(dat, symbol != "UNRATE")  Check that the unemployment-rate data are read in correctly:
head(ur)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 2 ## date ur ## <date> <dbl> ## 1 1960-01-01 5.2 ## 2 1960-02-01 4.8 ## 3 1960-03-01 5.4 ## 4 1960-04-01 5.2 ## 5 1960-05-01 5.1 ## 6 1960-06-01 5.4  tail(ur)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 2 ## date ur ## <date> <dbl> ## 1 2018-12-01 3.9 ## 2 2019-01-01 4 ## 3 2019-02-01 3.8 ## 4 2019-03-01 3.8 ## 5 2019-04-01 3.6 ## 6 2019-05-01 3.6  Generate inflation data as percent change from one year ago:
$$ \text{percent change from year ago} = \left( \frac{ x_t }{ x_{t-12} } - 1 \right) \times 100. $$
dat <- dat %>% group_by(symbol) %>% mutate(infl = (price/lag(price, n = 12) - 1)*100) %>% drop_na() # Rename series dat <- dat %>% mutate(series_name = case_when(symbol == "CPILFESL" ~ "Less food and energy", symbol == "CPIAUCSL" ~ "All items"))  Plot the data:
ggplot(data = dat) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = infl, color = series_name)) + labs(x = "", y = "Percent", color = "") + ggtitle("Inflation") + theme_bw()  Regressions The goal now is seeing the relationship between the unemployment rate and inflation. Specifically, we’re interested in the regressions $$ \text{inflation}_t = \alpha + \beta \; \text{unemployment rate}_t + \varepsilon_t $$ for each of the inflation series. We’re interested in reporting the $ \beta $s.
To do so, we need to get the data in this form:
dat <- dat %>% left_join(ur, by = "date") head(dat)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 6 ## # Groups: symbol [1] ## symbol date price infl series_name ur ## <chr> <date> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <dbl> ## 1 CPIAUCSL 1961-01-01 29.8 1.60 All items 6.6 ## 2 CPIAUCSL 1961-02-01 29.8 1.46 All items 6.9 ## 3 CPIAUCSL 1961-03-01 29.8 1.46 All items 6.9 ## 4 CPIAUCSL 1961-04-01 29.8 0.914 All items 7 ## 5 CPIAUCSL 1961-05-01 29.8 0.913 All items 7.1 ## 6 CPIAUCSL 1961-06-01 29.8 0.777 All items 6.9  tail(dat)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 6 ## # Groups: symbol [1] ## symbol date price infl series_name ur ## <chr> <date> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <dbl> ## 1 CPILFESL 2018-12-01 260. 2.21 Less food and energy 3.9 ## 2 CPILFESL 2019-01-01 261. 2.15 Less food and energy 4 ## 3 CPILFESL 2019-02-01 261. 2.08 Less food and energy 3.8 ## 4 CPILFESL 2019-03-01 261. 2.04 Less food and energy 3.8 ## 5 CPILFESL 2019-04-01 262. 2.07 Less food and energy 3.6 ## 6 CPILFESL 2019-05-01 262. 2.00 Less food and energy 3.6  Now we’re interested in a function that regresses infl on ur and returns the coefficient on ur. The input of the function will be data frame. We’re interested in data frames because there are essentially two datasets, one for each of the inflation series. This is done using R’s nest, which creates a new data structure:
dat <- dat %>% group_by(series_name) %>% nest() dat  ## # A tibble: 2 x 2 ## series_name data ## <chr> <list> ## 1 All items <tibble [701 x 5]> ## 2 Less food and energy <tibble [701 x 5]>  Each row of the data column is data frame:
dat$data[[1]]  ## # A tibble: 701 x 5 ## symbol date price infl ur ## <chr> <date> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 CPIAUCSL 1961-01-01 29.8 1.60 6.6 ## 2 CPIAUCSL 1961-02-01 29.8 1.46 6.9 ## 3 CPIAUCSL 1961-03-01 29.8 1.46 6.9 ## 4 CPIAUCSL 1961-04-01 29.8 0.914 7 ## 5 CPIAUCSL 1961-05-01 29.8 0.913 7.1 ## 6 CPIAUCSL 1961-06-01 29.8 0.777 6.9 ## 7 CPIAUCSL 1961-07-01 29.9 1.25 7 ## 8 CPIAUCSL 1961-08-01 29.9 1.11 6.6 ## 9 CPIAUCSL 1961-09-01 30.0 1.25 6.7 ## 10 CPIAUCSL 1961-10-01 30.0 0.773 6.5 ## # ... with 691 more rows  Now we’re interested in a function that takes one of these data frames as inputs.
my_reg <- function(df) { fit <- lm(infl ~ ur, data = df) # Return the unemployment-rate coefficient return(fit$coefficients[["ur"]]) }  And we want to use R’s map function to return the coefficients:
dat <- dat %>% mutate(coefficient = map(data, my_reg)) %>% unnest(coefficient) dat  ## # A tibble: 2 x 3 ## series_name data coefficient ## <chr> <list> <dbl> ## 1 All items <tibble [701 x 5]> 0.230 ## 2 Less food and energy <tibble [701 x 5]> 0.371  The dataset now contains the coefficients from the two regressions.

summary: Person re-identification is a critical security task for recognizing a person across spatially disjoint sensors. Previous work can be computationally intensive and is mainly based on low-level cues extracted from RGB data and implemented on a PC for a fixed sensor network (such as traditional CCTV). We present a practical and efficient framework for mobile devices (such as smart phones and robots) where high-level semantic soft biometrics are extracted from RGB and depth data. By combining these cues, our approach attempts to provide robustness to noise, illumination, and minor variations in clothing. This mobile approach may be particularly useful for the identification of persons in areas ill-served by fixed sensors or for tasks where the sensor position and direction need to dynamically adapt to a target. Results on the BIWI dataset are preliminary but encouraging. Further evaluation and demonstration of the system will be available on our website.
title: A Person Re-Identification System For Mobile Devices

content: More detail can easily be written here using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: We present a mobile visual clothing search system whereby a smart phone user can either choose a social networking photo or take a new photo of a person wearing clothing of interest and search for similar clothing in a retail database. From the query image, the person is detected, clothing is segmented, and clothing features are extracted and quantized. The information is sent from the phone client to a server, where the feature vector of the query image is used to retrieve similar clothing products from online databases. The phone's GPS location is used to re-rank results by retail store location. State of the art work focuses primarily on the recognition of a diverse range of clothing offline and pays little attention to practical applications. Evaluated on a challenging dataset, the system is relatively fast and achieves promising results.
title: Mobile visual clothing search
